source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_019_chunk3
evidence_span: In a typical operating PWR, the primary coolant normally contains a basic additive [for example, lithium hydroxide (LiOH) or ammonium hydroxide $( \mathbf { N H } _ { 4 } \mathbf { O H } )$ at nominal (room temperature) $\mathfrak { p H }$ of 10] to minimize corrosion and corrosion transport of plant materials, additions of hydrogen (or ammonia, or both) to reduce the oxygen concentration in the coolant, oxygen levels maintained below 0.05 ppm oxygen by virtue of the hydrogen additions, and possibly a chemical shim, usually boric acid, in the range 0 to 2500 ppm boron.

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_019_chunk3
evidence_span: Under these highly reducing conditions, it is the general consensus that either Zircaloy does not experience an irradiation-induced acceleration in the corrosion processes $[ I O , I 7 -$ 21] or, if excess corrosion is present, its magnitude is too small for typical PWR lifetimes to be detected within the uncertainties associated with the ability to predict anticipated corrosion behavior.

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_019_chunk3
evidence_span: exposures to high fast neutron flux levels are involved, acceleration factors of 2.0 to 2.5 (that is, observed weight gain divided by predicted weight gain from time-temperature history) have been encountered, even in the "highly reducing" environments [22].

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_019_chunk3
evidence_span: Even with the 2.5-fold increase, the total corrosion product formation $( \neg 1 1 \ \mu \mathbf { m }$ , maximum) did not detract from the normal operation of the reactor.

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_019_chunk3
evidence_span: It has been shown repeatedly that in PWR systems where there has been either deliberate or inadvertent additions of oxygen to the coolant, the presence of fast neutron flux (or fluence) produces a pronounced enhancement of the Zircaloy corrosion rate [21,23-26].

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_019_chunk3
evidence_span: It also has been observed that when the oxygen content in the coolant is high, a very dramatic reduction in hydrogen pickup is produced, whereas smaller oxygen contents can result in only minor decreases in hydrogen absorption [15].

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_019_chunk3
evidence_span: Boiling Water Reactors (BWR)-Boiling water reactors normally are operated in pure (neutral) water with the radiolytic decomposition gases hydrogen and oxygen being stripped continually from the water into the steam phase.

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_019_chunk3
evidence_span: A typical operating environment for a BWR may contain as much as $0 . 3 \ \mathsf { p p m }$ oxygen in the water and 20 ppm oxygen in the steam [28].

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_019_chunk3
evidence_span: A typical operating environment for a BWR may contain as much as $0 . 3 \ \mathsf { p p m }$ oxygen in the water and 20 ppm oxygen in the steam [28].

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_019_chunk3
evidence_span: Fog-cooled and superheated steam irradiation facilities have been known to operate with 20 to 30 ppm oxygen in the corrosion environment [28].

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_019_chunk3
evidence_span: Due to the oxygenated environment, the corrosion of Zircaloy-2 and -4 in BWRs is enhanced over that experienced in ex-reactor experiments [15,29-39].

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_019_chunk3
evidence_span: Due to the oxygenated environment, the corrosion of Zircaloy-2 and -4 in BWRs is enhanced over that experienced in ex-reactor experiments [15,29-39].

evidence_span: Both fast neutron flux and temperature play important roles. The presence of fast neutron flux decreases the temperature sensitivity of the Zircaloy corrosion processes in the oxygenated media.
